title: Fix: Remove Python::with_gil() wrapper from __next__() - re-acquiring GIL defeats allow_threads() release
description:
CRITICAL FINDING: GIL is still NOT being released even after removing Python::with_gil() wrapper.

Root cause identified: The allow_threads() method on a bound Python<'py> handle (obtained via PyRefMut::py()) does not actually release the GIL in PyO3 0.27.

Evidence:
- Sequential read of 100k records: 0.85s
- Parallel read of 2x 100k records (2 threads): 1.95s each (~0.44x speedup)
- Expected speedup with GIL release: 1.8x
- Both threads take same time (~1.95s), indicating serial execution, not parallel

The threading.Event test shows that SOME other thread activity can occur (suggesting the GIL might be released momentarily), but not enough for parallelism.

PyO3 0.27 API changes:
- allow_threads() is deprecated
- Should use Python::detach().allow_threads() or similar pattern
- Bound Python<'py> might not support GIL release in same way as unbound Python<'unbound>

Next: Investigate correct PyO3 0.27 pattern for actual GIL release on a bound Python handle.
notes: RESOLVED: Code uses py.detach() correctly. Real issue is architectural: Python file I/O requires GIL. Mitigation: Phase H RustFile backend needed for parallelism.

- Each thread must acquire GIL for Phase 1 I/O (sequential bottleneck)

- Part A: Error conversion fix - use py.detach() instead of allow_threads() [DONE]
- Part B: Batch reading (Phase C) - read multiple records per Phase 1, parse batch in Phase 2 [REQUIRED]

- Error conversion deferred to Phase 3 [DONE]
- py.detach() properly releases GIL [DONE]

title: GIL Release: Unlock threading parallelism in pymrrc
description:
GIL Release: Unlock threading parallelism in pymrrc

See: @docs/design/GIL_RELEASE_IMPLEMENTATION_PLAN.md

Goal: Enable GIL release during I/O operations to achieve 2-3x threading speedup on concurrent workloads.

Architecture:
Three-phase pattern separates Python object access (requires GIL) from CPU-intensive parsing (can release GIL):

title: Enable GIL release in pymrrc I/O operations
description:
Enable GIL release in pymrrc I/O operations to unlock threading parallelism.

Current State:
- Python::attach() HOLDS the GIL during all file I/O
- This blocks other Python threads from running
- Expected improvement: 1.41x â†’ 3.4x speedup for concurrent reads (currently not achieved)

Root Cause:
- PyFileWrapper holds Py<PyAny> (Python file object reference)
- Py<T> requires the GIL to be held - it's not Send without GIL
- When we try to use detach() or pass it between threads, PyO3 rejects it

Required Fix:
1. Restructure I/O layer to separate Python object management from actual I/O
   - Move Python file object interaction to wrapper layer
   - Make core reading/writing logic independent of Python references
2. Use PyO3's allow_threads or detach() to explicitly release GIL during:
   - read_record() in readers.rs - the actual MarcReader::read_record() call
   - write_record() in writers.rs - the actual MarcWriter::write_record() call  
3. Option A: Create intermediate buffer/bytes that don't hold Python refs
   - PyFileWrapper reads into Vec<u8> while holding GIL
   - Pass bytes to Rust code WITHOUT Python refs
   - Rust code processes without GIL held
4. Option B: Use separate thread pool with GIL management
   - More complex but cleaner API

Implementation Steps:
- Refactor PyFileWrapper to not hold references during I/O operations
- Add allow_threads decorator or use detach() pattern
- Update PyO3 decorators in src-python/src/readers.rs and writers.rs
- Benchmark threading after implementation
- Verify pymrrc matches Rust parallelism efficiency

Depends on: Phase 2 results showing current threading limitation
close_reason: Obsolete: Superseded by Phase H RustFile implementation which provides true parallelism via pure Rust I/O. This investigation task was for Python file object approach which has architectural GIL limitations.

title: Fix Phase 2: Use Python::assume_gil_acquired() instead of bound py.allow_threads()
description:

The issue: py.allow_threads() on a bound Python<'py> handle (from PyRefMut) does not actually release the GIL.

The solution: Use Python::assume_gil_acquired() to get an unbound Python handle that properly supports GIL release.

2. Safety guarantee: PyRefMut guarantees GIL is held, so assume_gil_acquired() is safe

3. This matches the exact pattern in the implementation plan (lines 187-189)

Expected Outcome:
- GIL will actually be released during Phase 2 parsing
- Threading speedup will jump from 0.83x to 1.8x+
- Two threads will execute truly concurrently
